terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Victorian countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Victorian event. Rolling terrain with difficult access, high costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravelista is a regional event in Victoria, Australia—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Victorian countryside is nice and organization is solid, but the difficult/expensive access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Victorian rolling gravel race. Worth it for Australian riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Australia—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Australian terrain: Devils Cardigan.

logistics.food: Victoria has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Victorian rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Starting at Seymour Racecourse provides proper race venue infrastructure, but the move from Beechworth in 2025 meant rebuilding operational systems. The 2025 event maintained all start times despite challenging weather, showing solid contingency planning, though basic lodging and travel information remains sparse.

length.explanation: The 135km course with 1,892m climbing delivered proper gravel distance—elite winner Brendan Johnston finished in 3:46:57, winning by just 3 seconds over Mark O'Brien. Multiple distance options (95km, 50km) accommodate different abilities without diluting the main event's challenge. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: This is 83% quality gravel on wide open roads through farmland, not technical singletrack. The 1km Wicket Hill Climb at 11% average grade is described as 'the crux of the course,' but it's power over bike handling skills that determines outcomes on these mostly rolling roads. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 1,892m of climbing over 135km keeps riders working without being mountainous. Wicket Hill's 125m gain hits twice in the long course, and elevation ranging from 155m to 520m provides constant undulation. Enough to separate the field but favors fitness over pure climbing specialists. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Late October typically offers ideal spring conditions, but 2025 showed weather's wild side. Race organizers described it bluntly: 'NO BLUE SKIES. NO DUST. NO WARMTH. Just rain. Cold. And heart.' The challenging conditions 'soaked riders to the bone' but the event proceeded as scheduled. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 155m and maxing at 520m means zero altitude considerations. This is essentially sea level for performance—no acclimatization needed, no training benefit, just normal oxygen levels throughout the Goulburn Valley terrain. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The course winds through rolling farmlands with Strathbogie Ranges vistas, reaching Wallaby Gully Flora Reserve at the highest point. Organizers call it 'some of the finest, fastest & least-known gravel in the country,' delivering countryside exploration without manufactured adventure.

prestige.explanation: Being the first UCI Gravel World Series qualifier worldwide for 2025 should elevate status, but the race remains relatively unknown despite over 500 participants. Matt Bird's crash report mentions hoping for 'something more exciting than a ripped skinsuit and bruised ego' at his 'first little gravel event.'

race_quality.explanation: The course delivers with 83% quality gravel and strategic design—Wicket Hill Climb creates selection points at 30km and 73km. The 2025 edition proved its mettle when challenging weather turned it into 'a test of grit, courage, and sheer determination' that riders won't forget.

experience.explanation: You're riding through Australian countryside with Strathbogie Ranges vistas that actually matter. Starting and finishing at Seymour Racecourse gives it proper event feel, and the two-loop format means spectators can see you suffer twice. The terrain from 155m to 520m elevation keeps the scenery changing, though the experience caps out at 'very pleasant' rather than life-changing.

community.explanation: The event welcomes everyone from 'UCI Age Category podium' chasers to those wanting to 'roll with mates,' with over 500 participants and growing. E-bikes are 'welcome, and encouraged' in recreational categories. Despite 2025's brutal weather, organizers thanked Seymour's warmth that 'shone through.'

field_depth.explanation: Over 500 riders creates decent competition across age groups, with UCI qualification drawing serious amateurs. Brendan Johnston's repeat victory and 3-second winning margin shows quality at the front, though the field lacks international depth beyond Oceania talent like 2025 NZ Cyclocross Champion Sharlotte Lucas. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: $215 AUD entry includes 135km of quality gravel, aid stations, and UCI Worlds qualification opportunity for top 25% finishers. The event village offers 'fine food & drink, local produce' plus $30 camping for six people maximum—reasonable pricing for a qualifier event.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150 AUD. Getting to Seymour, Victoria means expensive international flights and costly domestic Australian travel. Limited accommodation details beyond Seymour being a 'hidden gem' suggests tight lodging options. Add bike shipping and rental cars, and total costs mount quickly for this relatively small event. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Gravelista 2024: The disastrous one
videos.description:
Things could have been worse at Gravelista 2024 in Seymour, Victoria, Australia, but not by much. An amazing gravel race event all the same. 

Thumbnail shot by @shotbyleealexand3r & @gravelista.cc 

Follow me on Instagram: http://instagram.com/longandwinding_mtb/

Please subscribe to support this channel – it's much appreciated! 

I'm not doing so much mountain bike at the moment, so this channel is all about my gravel and road riding adventures and races. There will be lots of race and event coverage, epics rides and routes and maybe even an interview to come in the future so stay tuned :-) 

My gear: 
Sony a7iv
GoPro Hero 9
DJI Air 2
Road: Specialized Tarmac SL8 Pro 2024
Gravel: Specialized Crux Expert 2023
MTB: 2021 Cannondale Scalpel SE Carbon 1

videos.curation_reason: First-person race recap with specific course details including Wickets Hill climb, creek crossings, and tactical insights from the race experience.

videos.title: 2025 Gravelista UCI Course Preview Seymour
videos.description:
Today’s ride takes me out of Melbourne and into the rural town of Seymour, Victoria, because in just 3 weeks time the 2025 UCI Gravel World Series begins with Gravelista, and I wanted to see if my legs are up for it.

This isn’t your Sunday coffee shop ride, this is Australia’s golden ticket to the 2026 UCI Gravel World Championships in Nannup, WA, and the course is about as forgiving as a magpie in swooping season.

My video kicks off just before Wickets Hill Road at Hughes Creek, jumping straight into the heart of the 135km and 95km Gravelista routes. With 82% gravel, rolling climbs, and fast open roads, the course is the perfect mix of punishment and fun. The main event? The infamous Wicket Hill Climb, 1km, averaging 11%, with 125m of gain. Short, sharp, savage… like a spicy meat pie fresh from the servo microwave.

Along the way you get farm tracks, the Wallaby Gully Flora Reserve and some relief on the sealed sections, and enough dust to keep the local laundromat in business. Feed zones might save you, but only if you pace smarter than your ego.

If you’re hunting Melbourne gravel rides, UCI Gravel World Series, or Victoria cycling routes, this course preview dishes it all up, minus the post-ride bbq.

Route: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/52398087 (135km)
Bike: https://youtu.be/D0SFrHfkPhI
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/11thwombat/

#gravelcycling #gravelbike #gravelride #bike #cycling #roadcycling #cyclinglife #bikelife #melbournecycling #11thwombat 

Chapters ʕ•ᴥ•ʔ
00:42 Wickets Hill Climb / Feed station # 1, 3 & 5
06:18 Fowles Winery / Feed station # 2 & 4
videos.curation_reason: Recent course preview specifically for Gravelista featuring Wickets Hill and Hughes Creek sections with good production quality.

videos.title: UCI Gravel World Series: Brendan Johnston Defends Title at Gravelista - Elite Results & Highlights
videos.description:
Dive into the thrilling UCI Gravel World Series Gravelista event in Australia, where Brendan Johnston defended his elite men's title against Mark O'Brien by just 3 seconds. Watch full results and highlights from the 135km race.
Sharlotte Lucas dominated the elite women's division, securing victory over Sophie Byrne. Discover top 10 finishes for both divisions, including Kevin Biffiger and Ella Bloor.
This gravel cycling race showcased intense competition on home terrain for Johnston, who recently placed ninth at the Life Time Grand Prix. Explore key moments, strategies, and rider interviews from the Seymour, Victoria event.
Perfect for cycling fans, gravel enthusiasts, and sports lovers tracking the UCI Gravel World Series. Stay updated with latest racing content, features, and expert insights in gravel biking.
videos.transcript:
Gravel racing just reached new heights
of intensity.
The UCI gravel world series in Seymour,
Victoria, showcased a thrilling battle
where every second counted. Brendan
Johnston, giant sramm, cemented his
dominance by defending his elite men's
title at Graalista, while Shalotte Lucas
Leaf emerged victorious in the elite
women's division, proving that grit and
determination reign supreme on the
gravel. But here's where it gets
controversial. Johnston's win was a
nilbiter as he edged out Australian
gravel champion Mark O'Brien by a mere 3
seconds over a grueling 135 km course.
Is this the closest finish we've seen in
gravel racing? Let us know your thoughts
in the comments.
Fresh off a ninth place finish at a Big
Sugar Classic in Arkansas, Johnston
returned to familiar terrain in Seymour,
ready to battle for his title. His
winning time of 3 hours 46 minutes and
57 seconds highlighted not just his
speed, but his strategic prowess in
holding off fierce competition.
Kevin Befiger secured third place 116
behind with Tessman Nangovis closely
following in fourth just 19 seconds
further back. The race was a testament
to the growing depth and talent in the
gravel racing scene and this is the part
most people miss. The elite women's race
was equally electrifying.
Charlotte Lucas dominated with a time of
4 hours 41 minutes and 1 second, leaving
Sophie Burn and Ella Blur to battle for
second and third, respectively.
Lucas's performance underscores the
rising prominence of women in gravel
racing, a trend that's reshaping the
sport. But what does this mean for the
future of gravel racing? Are we seeing a
shift in the competitive landscape?
Share your opinions below. Here's a
breakdown of the top finishes.
Elite Men top 10. One, Brendan Johnston,
3 hours 46 minutes and 57 seconds.
Two, Mark O'Brien, plus 03.
Three, Kevin Befiger + 1 16.
Four, Tessman Ankovis + 1 35.
Five, Aston Key + 232.
6 Ben Medel + 2 col 33.
Seven, Scott Bowen + 413.
Eight, Jack Atken + 48.
Nine, Harry Leisk, + 49.
10, Ben Spence Lelay, + 5 20. Elite
Woman.
One, Charotte Lucas, 4 hours 41 minutes
and 1 second. Two, Sophie Burn, + 321.
Three, Ella Blue + 723.
Four, Color Bell + 74.
Five, Brianna Samuel + 1206.
6 Juliet Hedo + 125
7 Britney Kerr + 28 57
DNF
Jessica Pratt. For those hungry for more
gravel racing insights, Jackie, a
seasoned sports professional with over
30 years of experience in news
reporting, sports marketing, and public
relations, offers a wealth of knowledge.
As the founder of Pelatin Sports and
Bike Alpharetta, Inc., she's no stranger
to the world of cycling.
her favorite rides. The serene horse
farms of North Georgia, the lavender
fields of Provence, and the thrilling
MTB trails of Park City, Utah. Her
expertise and passion make her a go-to
source for all things cycling.
Stay tuned for more race content,
interviews, features, reviews, and
expert buying guides delivered straight
to your inbox.

videos.title: UCI Gravel World Series: Brendan Johnston & Sharlotte Lucas Win! | Gravelista Recap
videos.description:
Get ready for an action-packed gravel race recap! The UCI Gravel World Series in Seymour, Victoria, delivered thrilling performances from the world's best. Brendan Johnston successfully defended his title, beating Mark O'Brien by a slim margin. Meanwhile, Sharlotte Lucas dominated the elite women's division.
Johnston, riding for Giant-SRAM, showcased his skills after a strong showing at the Life Time Grand Prix. He conquered the 135km course in 3:46:57, just seconds ahead of O'Brien. Kevin Biffiger completed the podium, followed closely by Tasman Nankervis.
In the women's race, Lucas took the top spot with a time of 4:41:01. Sophie Byrne and Ella Bloor rounded out the podium.
This event showcased the excitement and competitiveness of gravel racing. Stay tuned for more UCI Gravel World Series updates and subscribe for all the latest cycling news!
videos.transcript:
Gravel racing is brutal, but defending a
title, that's legendary.
Brendan Johnston just proved it's
possible, while Charotte Lucas sees
victory in the elite women's race at
Gravilista.
But the real story isn't just about
winning. It's about the grit, the
strategy, and the sheer determination it
takes to conquer these grueling courses.
Let's dive into the details of this
Australian round of the UCI Gravel World
Series held in Seymour, Victoria, and
what made these wins so remarkable. Just
a week after securing a solid ninth
place at the Lifetime Grand Prix's Big
Sugar Classic in Arkansas, Brendan
Johnston, giant SRAMM, returned to his
familiar stomping grounds, laser focused
on defending his Gravilista title. The
135 km course was a true test of
endurance and tactical prowess with
Johnston ultimately fending off a fierce
challenge from Australian gravel
champion Mark O'Brien. The margin of
victory, a mere 3 seconds. Johnston
crossed the finish line in a blistering
3 hours 46 minutes and 57 seconds, a
testament to his unwavering commitment.
Kevin Biffiger followed in third, 1
minute and 16 seconds behind Johnston
with Tasmin close behind a further 19
seconds a drift in fourth place. The
competition was fierce, showcasing the
depth of talent in the men's elite
field. And this is the part most people
miss. Gravel racing isn't just about
power. It's about navigating
unpredictable terrain, making
split-second decisions, and enduring
conditions that can change in an
instant.
Johnston's ability to anticipate
O'Brien's moves and maintain that razor
thin lead speaks volumes about his
experience and mental fortitude. On the
women's side, Charlotte Lucas live
claimed the elite women's title with an
impressive performance, finishing in 4
hours 41 minutes and 1 second. Sophie
Burn secured second place, trailing
Lucas by 3 minutes and 21 seconds. Ella
Blur rounded out the podium in third,
finishing 7 minutes and 23 seconds
behind the leader. Carla Bell was hot on
her heels, finishing only 1 second
behind in fourth place. Brianna Samuel
finished fifth, 12 minutes and 6 seconds
behind Lucas with Juliet Hado in sixth
and Britney Kerr in seventh. Jessica
Pratt unfortunately did not finish the
race. Here's a thought. Does the
relatively small time gap between
Johnston and O'Brien suggest that course
familiarity played a significant role in
the men's race? Or was it purely a
matter of superior strategy and
execution in the final moments? It's
definitely something to consider,
especially given Johnston's experience
on the course. UCI Gravel World Series
gravy list of results. Elite Men top 10.
Poss Writer Time. One, Brendan Johnston,
3 hours 46 minutes and 57 seconds. Two,
Mark O'Brien, plus 03.
Three, Kevin Biff Iger + 1 16 for Tasmin
plus 1 35.
Five, Aston Key + 232.
6, Ben Metc + 2 33.
Seven, Scott Bowden plus for colon 13.
Eight, Jack Aiken plus 4 col 18. Nine,
Harry Le plus for colon 19. 10, Ben
Spencili + 5 col 20. Elite women pause
name time. One, Charlotte Lucas for
hours 41 minutes and 1 second. Two,
Sophie Burn + 321.
Three, Ella Blur + 723
for Carla Bell + 74.
Five, Brianna Samuel + 1206.
6 Juliet Hado + 125
Seven Brittany Kerr + 2857
Jessica Pratt DNF.
What do you think? Was Brendan
Johnston's victory a testament to
experience or did Mark O'Brien simply
run out of road? And how crucial is bike
setup and tire choice in a race like
Gravilista?
Share your thoughts and predictions for
the rest of the UCI Gravel World Series
season in the comments below.

videos.title: Brendan Johnston Defends UCI Gravel Title at Gravelista! Sharlotte Lucas Wins Women's Elite
videos.description:
UCI Gravel World Series Gravelista race highlights: Brendan Johnston (Giant-SRAM) repeats as elite men's champion, edging out Mark O'Brien by just 3 seconds in Seymour, Victoria. Sharlotte Lucas (Liv) dominates elite women with a 4:41:01 victory.
Watch the thrilling 135km gravel race action from Australia's UCI Gravel World Series event. After his 9th at Big Sugar Classic, Johnston shines on home turf, finishing in 3:46:57. Full results breakdown:
Elite Men Top 5: 1. Brendan Johnston, 2. Mark O’Brien (+0:03), 3. Kevin Biffiger (+1:16), 4. Tasman Nankervis (+1:35), 5. Aston Key (+2:32).
Elite Women: 1. Sharlotte Lucas, 2. Sophie Byrne (+3:21), 3. Ella Bloor (+7:23).
Dive into gravel cycling excitement, rider interviews, and expert analysis. Perfect for fans of off-road racing, UCI events, and Australian gravel scenes.
Subscribe for more UCI Gravel World Series coverage, cycling news, and race recaps!
videos.transcript:
The UCI Gravel World Series ignites
passion and competition and the
Graalista event in Seymour, Victoria,
delivered an intense battle. Brendan
Johnston, a giant SRAMM rider, proved
his dominance once again, securing the
elite men's title for the second time.
But the rail story lies in the narrow
margin of victory. Johnston, fresh from
a top 10 finish at the lifetime Grand
Prix, faced a fierce challenge from
Australian champion Mark O'Brien on his
home turf. In a thrilling race, Johnston
emerged triumphant, crossing the finish
line a mere 3 seconds ahead of O'Brien.
Kevin Biffer completed the podium 1
minute and 16 seconds behind with Tasmin
in fourth. The elite women's race saw
Charlatee Lucas of Liv take the top step
on the podium, showcasing her prowess in
the 135 km course. She finished in 4
hours 41 minutes and 1 second with
Sophie Burn and Ella Blur rounding out
the top three. But here's where it gets
intriguing. The women's race had a
larger time gap between the winner and
second place, raising questions about
the depth of the women's field. Is this
a one-off or a trend worth exploring
further? The Graalista event, part of
the UCI Gravel World Series, offered a
thrilling showcase of talent and
strategy. And this is just the
beginning. With the series gaining
popularity, we can expect more dramatic
races and rising stars. But what do you
think? Are gravel races the future of
cycling or a passing fad? Share your
thoughts and let's spark a conversation.

quotes.text: The course started at Seymour Race Course headed out over Wickets Hill which is the only real major climb in this course and then it did a big loop the 136k riders did it twice and the 95k riders did it once. There was a creek crossing coming up and I wanted to pick my line through this but it ended up just sending it straight through the middle anyway.

We were on and off the tarmac but eventually settled into the gravel and there was a few attempts at breakaways early on and I was involved in pretty much all of them. We went through a really big muddy puddle which I unfortunately missed - I was too worried about my position.
